nodes.text: Heap Nine was a junk world where scavengers picked at the remnants of a long-dead civilization. In 3 ABY, the Rebel Alliance's 61st Mobile Infantry took a rest stop at the world during its own campaign. Some of the 61st's personnel took dropships to the surface, and three of them, Hazram Namir, Gadren and Brand visited a cantina at a settlement. After Namir failed in his flirting with a patron, Gadren bought his comrade three drinks and the pair then walked down a street talking of past deployments.
By the time of the Galactic Civil War, Heap Nine was a junker world which had at least one settlement. The settlement included junk shops and scrap traders.

Heap Nine was once home to a civilization which, by the time of the Galactic Civil War, was eventually reduced to garbage piles. During the war, scavengers picked at what was left of the civilization, and the world was unnoticed by the Galactic Empire. In 3 ABY, the Rebel Alliance's 61st Mobile Infantry, which had been fighting a campaign along the Rimma Trade Route, stopped at Heap Nine overnight to give their personnel some rest as proposed by the ex-Imperial Governor Everi Chalis and Chief Medic Von Geiz.

Some of the 61st, including the assumed Captain Hazram Namir, the Besalisk Gadren and the ex-bounty hunter Brand, took dropships to the surface of Heap Nine from the 61st's CR90 corvette the Thunderstrike. Namir, Brand and Gadren visited an open-air cantina at Heap Nine's settlement, where the former two tried to flirt with two respective patrons. Although Brand was successful and left with her new friend, Namir was rejected by the patron he had spoken to. Gadren bought the captain three drinks, the pair speaking about whether Namir looked like a fool.

Namir and Gadren then walked down the streets of the settlement and talked of past deployments, Gadren recounting the 61st's time on Ferrok Pax. Gadren used the story to advise Namir that the captain feared the sacrifices that the 61st had taken and would take during its ongoing campaign. Some hours later, the dropships returned to the Thunderstrike with Namir, Gadren and Brand, and the 61st moved onto its next target.
Heap Nine appeared in Alexander Freed's 2015 novel Battlefront: Twilight Company.
